title: The recreations of Christopher North
author: Wilson, John
snippet: All the Four Lochs, we understand, are there still; but the Little Loch transmogrified into an auxiliar appurtenance to some cursed Wark — the Brother Loch much exhausted by daily drains upon him by we know not what wretch — the White Loch lurched — and the Black Loch of a ghastly blue, criieliy cultivated  all close round the brim.

title: Later letters of Marcus Dods, D. D. (late principal of New college, Edinburgh) (1895-1909)
author: Dods, Marcus
snippet: [Edinburgh, 2Uh December 1903.] Thanks from here to Wark.

title: The complete poetical and prose works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: He speedily obtained possession ofthe Border fortresses of Norham, Wark, EtalLFord, and others of less note, and collected a greatspoil.

title: Journal of a Summer Tour in the Perthshire and Inverness-shire Highlands
author: Roger, James Cruikshank.
snippet: Work or Wark is an old Scotch term derivedfrom the Icelandic virki, a fortification.

title: Early Travellers in Scotland. Edited by P. Hume Brown. [With maps.]
author: Brown, Peter Hume.
snippet: Which homward from thence thei shal returne complete,Four and twentie myles to Lamarke so shene,2To Pebles on Twede, is syxtene myles I wene,To Soltray3 as muche, then twentie miles w* spede;From thence returne they shal to Wark on Twede.
